title: Wednesday, 27th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

RabbleFest tonight

PM11:01am

Do come along if you can

11:01 am
PM11:01am

6pm till late

PM11:01am

Bleeding Heart Tavern

PM11:02am

Greville St

11:02 am
undefined
PM11:02am

Kicking around for an image...

PM11:02am

This class war games stuff went a bit nuts yesterday after being featured here

PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Paul Mason saying it's gonna be like Stanligrad if/when Corbyn gets into power

PM11:03am

Really?

PM11:04am

Hope not.

PM11:04am

Actually, Stanlingrad can be our pic for today

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Little-known fact: Paul Mason used to be a journalist!

PM11:04am

Yeah, BBC

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:05am

I could share other images of Stanligrad, but they are not suitable for a family show like this

PM11:05am

If you want to catch up on the labour class war stuff go here

PM11:05am

http://www.classwa....net/?page_id=4375

11:05 am
PM11:05am

And here https://gamesforthemany.com/

PM11:06am

But we'll not linger

PM11:06am

Need to go to markets

11:05 am
undefined
PM11:06am

Index becalmed again -- but (again) that doesn't reflect some turmoil below

PM11:07am

And some of it's 'up' turmoil

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Like Pearson

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 603.50, up 20 (+3.43%), High: 609.50, Low: 583.50, Volume: 2.43m
BE11:07am

Cripes!

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Exane's had a bit of a turn.

PM11:07am

Indeed

PM11:08am

But being Exane I haven't seen what they're saying

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Two-tier market -- thanks to regulation

BE11:08am

I have! Well, I've seen a bit of it.

BE11:08am

Sami Kassab's the analyst

11:08 am
PM11:09am

Public service this, Bryce - -levelling the research playing field

BE11:09am

Theme is textbook sales stabilising so perhaps the next update from Pearson won't be a warning.

PM11:09am

Sami's putting his proverbials on the line, surely?

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Yeah -- it also heads into how Pearson reinvents itself in a world where stuff like diagrams of oxbow lakes should probably be free.

BE11:10am

"personalised learning solutions using Artificial Intelligence offer a credible defence" against free stuff, he says.

BE11:10am

Which is a view, I guess.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Anyway, back to the top.

PM11:11am

A rosy view

BE11:11am

US Higher Education has been the main driver of Pearson’s derating. While there are still challenges ahead, the recent turn in the group’s strategy and potential positive newsflow with Q3 results should help the shares recover. We upgrade to Outperform.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Our channel check suggests that the college publishing market has returned to stability during the key summer selling season. More disciplined bookstore ordering coupled with the publishers’ push against counterfeit textbooks may have helped. This bodes well for Q3 results (17 October).

BE11:12am

Longer term, Pearson still has to prove its strategy can lead to a sustainable return to growth.
However, we believe it is making good progress. The pending sales of K12 courseware, Wall
Street English and GEDU reduce the group’s exposure to Open Education Resources (OER) threat
and to competition from online language platforms. Its group simplification, cost-cutting efforts and
technology upgrade projects are well on track, in our view.

BE11:12am

We raise our US Higher Ed Publishing organic revenue growth forecast from -7% to 0% for FY17 on the back of a stronger Q3. Consensus is at -7%. In the long run, moving to a textbook consignment model should improve college publishing economics. New personalised learning solutions using Artificial Intelligence offer a credible defence against OER. Higher forecasts for US Higher Education mitigated by FX are the main drivers behind our EPS revisions.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Expectations on Pearson are running low. Its dividend has been rebased. The stock trades on EV/EBIT18e of 9.5x (9x pro-forma for disposals), close to its 10-year lows and below its peers. The structural risks – with OER the main one – and the difficulty to forecast certainly justify a discount, but we think the current share price offers a good entry point. We turn Outperform.

PM11:13am

I note Deutsche have slapped a Sell on Pearson today. They must be feeling a tad sore at the positive reaction to Sami's stuff.

PM11:13am

Target price cut from 600p to 470p

11:14 am
BE11:14am

DB haven't sent it out, oddly.

PM11:15am

Maybe because of the price move...

PM11:15am

Pearson also appointed a "chief strategy officer" today

11:15 am
PM11:15am

This chap https://www.linkedin.com/in/jonathancm/

PM11:15am

Good luck to him

undefined
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Not much to say about Carillion ....

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 55.00, up 8.5 (+18.28%), High: 56.00, Low: 51.50, Volume: 13.38m
PM11:16am

Omg smile

11:16 am
BE11:16am

...... which is on the back of this story.

BE11:16am

http://www.cityam....keover-attempt-and

BE11:17am

At least one Middle Eastern construction firm is eyeing Carillion’s update this Friday ahead of a potential takeover bid for the struggling builder.

Final touches are being put to an offer from a new suitor to buy up Carillion’s shares and give the operator access to the firm’s London listing, City A.M. understands.

The bidder plans to submit a letter of intent to take control of the firm. However, it is waiting for the extent of Carillion’s financial woes to be laid bare at the end of this week before committing to a bid.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

..................................... hm.

PM11:17am

Love the phrase "final touches"

PM11:18am

Dotting i-s and crossing t-s

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Hey, the bid might happen Bryce!

BE11:18am

"Final touches" is two steps on from "running the slide rule".

BE11:18am

So yes, it might!

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Perhaps at least one unidentified Middle Eastern construction firm is ready to buy Carillion for ..... its ............ London listing.

PM11:20am

We'll see

BE11:20am

...... and net debt of £695m or thereabouts.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Want a preview of Carillion numbers? Becauise they'll be shocking.

PM11:21am

And it's pension deficit, remember

PM11:21am

Preview away

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Not sure why mysterious Middle Eastern bidder(s) need(s) to wait, we know they'll be shocking and the only question with Carillion is whether its liabilities exceed its assets.

BE11:22am

Morgan Stanley.

BE11:22am

The warning in July included a full review of the contract base and capital structure, departure of the CEO (the CFO has also subsequently been replaced), and a change in FY guidance. The company expects 1H revenue to be ~£2.5bn, with EBITA lower than previous expectations due to the phasing of PPP equity disposals, which should be weighted in 2H. Following the warning, we reduced our FY17-19e EPS estimates by 19-22% due to lower revenues, margins and higher interest costs. Organic growth for FY17e was lowered to -9% with sales of £4.8bn and EBITA of £222m for FY17e vs. £5.3bn and £251m previously.
The 1H results should provide an update on the business review, which should also include necessary actions to reduce average net debt. This could possibly include: 1) disposals (it flagged £125m in 12 months from non-core markets); 2) increase in cost saving estimates; and 3) receivables recovery. Previous guidance suggested ND could be reduced by £25-50m per annum, but this is expected to come to £695m vs. £587m at FY16.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

What to look out for:

Group organic growth, revenue and margins: MSe 1H17 revenue of £2,433m is -2.2%
YoY with organic growth of -4.3%, EBITA of £116.7m implying a margin of 4.8%, -
8bps YoY.
Divisionally: Support Services organic growth of +2.0% with margins -11bps YoY.
Middle East Construction and Construction Services ex. ME organic growth to
decline by -10% and total Construction services margins at 3.2% (-2bps YoY). MSe
organic growth in PPP is 2% and margin to improve to 14.8% (+106bps YoY).
Order book and pipeline: The trading update indicated that new order intake was
£2.6bn at 1H17 and the order book stood at £16bn, equivalent to FY16. Revenue
coverage for 2017 at 94% at the 1H trading update vs. 74% at FY15.
Updating for FX increases our FY17/19e EPS by 0.3-0.4

BE11:23am

Still .... nice to have a bid rumour kicking about when you're looking down the barrel of a rescue rights issue.

undefined
11:23 am
PM11:24am

Stick with the risers or go looking for damage?

PM11:24am

Damage is more fun, perhaps

BE11:24am

What falls into that category?

11:24 am
Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 234.75, down 24 (-9.28%), High: 268.00, Low: 228.25, Volume: 25.80m
BE11:24am

Ah.

PM11:24am

It's kinda harsh -- given the figure

11:24 am
PM11:25am

But the rating was just too damn high

PM11:25am

Interims here https://www.invest...1709270700069002R/

BE11:25am

Well, yes, when you're on a three-digit PE don't warn on margins.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Warning to the upside on revenues, mind

BE11:26am

Because when you do, people are likely to go digging through for other problems

PM11:26am

What else might they find?

11:26 am
BE11:26am

That upside on revenue, for instance, is acquisitions not organic.

BE11:27am

Okay, it's weird acquisitions in a kind of family fiefdom structure .... but still.

BE11:28am

Pretty Little Thing is doing amazing numbers. That's the main reason for sales going vertical.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Sheesh -- revenue up 289% there

PM11:28am

How about Nasty Gal. That's early stage, i assume

BE11:29am

Uh, ahead of consensus but still only doing £5m or so of sales.

11:29 am
PM11:29am

With their Nasty Galaxy...

PM11:01am

Welcome to ML

BE11:29am

........................... K.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Meanwhile ....

BE11:29am

as a result of significantly better than expected revenue growth from PLT and investment in price, promotion and marketing, now expect adjusted EBITDA margins to be between 9% and 10%

BE11:30am

Prior guidance was for an EBITDA margin of 10%.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

So, it's a downgrade.

BE11:30am

Barclays:

BE11:30am

Company consensus is currently for an EBITDA margin of 10.4%, we have 11.4%. Mechanically rev growth of 80% and an EBITDA margin of 9.5% implies an EBITDA of £50.5m. Current cons is £52m. *

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And Citi.

BE11:31am

BOO is expecting full year sales
growth of around +80% (from 60%, Citi +81%), implying 2H growth of c.+60%, and adjusted EBITDA margin of around 9-10% (from 10%), implying EBITDA of £48- 53m (Citi £54.2, cons £53.3m). Given higher depreciation and share based payment charges this implies FY18e PBT of c£34-39m (Citi £45m, cons £43.5m).
 Implications — FY18e consensus PBT expected fall materially — Although
boohoo raised absolute EBITDA guidance, a combination of consensus being ahead of guidance and larger than expected costs below EBITDA means that the implied guided range for FY18e PBT of £34-39m is 10-13% below current consensus. For the record, Citi forecast FY18e PBT of £45m, (EPS 3.17p, +47.2% yoy), based on sales growth of +81%, GM -200bps and EBIT margins down - 190bps yoy.
 Neutral, Target price 270p — Our 270p target price is based on a 10-year DCF.
This incorporates a +28% 2018-28e sales CAGR and a terminal EBIT margin of 9.5%. On 2019e numbers, this equates to a 4.1x EV/Sales multiple and a 64x PE.

BE11:32am

And Peel Hunt, which keeps the faith.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

boohoo’s guidance has been notoriously conservative, meaning analysts have largely ignored it.
However, upgraded revenue guidance of 80% growth for the year (up from 60%
and ahead of our previous 71% forecast) looks more realistic. We up our own
sales forecast to 84% growth, but take on board management’s guided EBITDA
margin of 9-10% (we are on 10%) to reflect the increased marketing spend. Our new EBITDA forecast of c£56m represents a c£1.2m upgrade. However, this is offset by higher share-based payments (noted above) to leave full-year PBT expectations unchanged

BE11:33am

The KPI set on all brands remains impressive, with
strong growth in actives, order frequency, basket and conversion
rate. Trading on over 5x sales, boohoo needs upgrades to fuel the
fire. These have come through at a sales and EBITDA level, but
are more muted in PBT terms due to non-cash share-based
payment charges (relating to the PLT acquisition) and
depreciation. Any weakness today represents a buying
opportunity as boohoo looks on track to deliver greater than £1bn in
revenues within 2-3 years.

PM11:34am

hmm

11:34 am
BE11:34am

£1bn in revenues would put Boohoo where M&S was in 2010.

PM11:34am

Which is extraordinary, to be fair

BE11:34am

Though I note it also as an example of how lines don't always go up.

11:34 am
undefined
PM11:36am

There's other stuff where the price has rather outstripped our expectations

BE11:36am

Such as?

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Such as Plus 500

Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 885.00, up 55 (+6.63%), High: 898.50, Low: 856.00, Volume: 559.53k
PM11:36am

Rocket

11:36 am
PM11:37am

Liberum were right to stick with this one -- through its troubles

PM11:37am

Profit warning -- to the upside

PM11:37am

https://www.invest...1709270700048966R/

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Let me see what Liberum are saying

PM11:37am

Plus500 has released a short trading update stating that the "business continues to trade strongly," and consequently revenues and profits for 2017 "will be ahead of market expectations." As a result we increase our Sterling EPS forecasts by 9% in 2017, and by 3% and 2% in 2018 and 2019, respectively. Continuing to value the company at 10x CY18 EPS, our new 1020p target price offers 23% upside. The CY18 dividend yield at our target price remains attractive at 7.4% and we reiterate our BUY rating. Plus500 will issue its Q3/17 IMS on 31 October.

PM11:38am

TP of 1020p

11:38 am
BE11:38am

...................... hm. I'm going to make a possibly existential observation here and suggest that companies can be measured on metrics other than whether their shares go up or down.

PM11:38am

We continue to value Plus500 at 10x CY18 EPS, to reach a target price of 1020p (previous: 992p). We believe the multiple we assign reflects an appropriate degree of caution in light of the regulatory threat from the ESMA proposals, which are as yet unknown.

Our 1020p target price yields 23% upside. The CY18 dividend yield at our target price remains attractive at 7.4%.

PM11:38am

That's all they are saying, really

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Justin Bates

BE11:39am

So, yes, Plus500 has been a good investment for those that kept the faith through the various controversies

PM11:39am

Fits with what we saw with Winterfloods yesterday -- there's plenty of retail action

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Maybe the punters are enjoying the lack of market structure...

BE11:40am

Exactly -- though with 'floods it's clearer to see where the money goes in and where it comes out.

BE11:40am

With Plus500, that's not quite so clear.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Berenberg:

BE11:41am

In H1 2017 Plus500 attracted 53,881 new customers, and active customers reached a record 112,317. Management
noted that the business generated 51% of its revenues from customers who
continue to trade with the company for longer than one year, with ARPU at
$1,678, reflecting the company’s focus on higher-value customers. At the
time we highlighted that this performance was achieved despite a 40% fall in the marketing spend, the biggest single cost for the company. Indeed, the average user acquisition cost (AUAC) in H1 2017 fell from $1,328 to $836. This boosted EBITDA margins to 63% (FY 2016: 46%). The unscheduled Q3 update today suggests that these trends have continued to
improve

BE11:41am

Changes to estimates: We upgrade our revenue estimates by 8%/6%/4% in
2017E/2018E/2019E; the increased margins lead to a larger increase in
adjusted EBITDA of 12%/10%/8% respectively.
● Valuation: We value Plus500 using a DCF, and discount the result by 30%
to account for the uncertain regulatory environment. Our upgraded
earnings forecasts prompt us to raise our price target by 7% from 875p to
940p. This leaves the business trading at a P/E of c7.4x/6.8x/6.3x
2017E/2018E/2019E, significantly less than peers IG Group and CMC, and
yielding 6.8%.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

I keep getting stuck on the customer acquisition cost of $836.

PM11:42am

I know, i know

BE11:42am

As in, the customer acquisition cost that's fallen from $1,328.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Is there any services business, any sector, any anything that throws so much cash at getting consumers to sign up?

PM11:44am

I genuinely can't think of a similar example

BE11:44am

Anyway, good luck to all holders. I'm sure regulation is exactly as distant a threat as the share price currently implies.

11:44 am
undefined
PM11:45am

Woah -- seen this attempt to corner the market in chicken???

PM11:45am

Yes, really

11:45 am
PM11:45am

This is from Clive Black and Darren Shirley

PM11:45am

Shore

PM11:45am

The poultry segment in the UK is a hot space at the moment. Following on from Boparan/2 Sister's Group consolidation of the British Isles' turkey market then Moy Park's acquisition by Pilgrim Pride, Cargill UK and Faccenda have announced the proposed amalgamation of their British chicken operations. The new venture will be a demonstrable new force in the market, further concentrating activities. No doubt the retail/foodservice segments will have a view on this combination as may the UK CMA. We also believe that this proposed merger could represent a potentially unexpected step forward for high quality Cranswick as it plans its road ahead in the fresh chicken market following its acquisition of the integrated Crown Chicken business.

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Cargill UK and Faccenda -- these are number 3 and 4 in the british chicken market, I believe

PM11:46am

This is a straightforward attempt to break the 'four-competitors' model of UK competition regs

PM11:46am

Outrageous

11:46 am
PM11:47am

Surely the CMA has got to come down hard on this deal

PM11:47am

Let me get some more Shore

PM11:47am

In a surprise move to us, albeit how shocked the trade was we are unsure, Cargill Chicken and Faccenda in the UK (Cargill is a USA based multi-functional player in the Agri-Food arena) announced yesterday (25th September 2017) that they are to create a newbusiness with equal shareholding. Yet to be named, the 50-50 venture incorporates Cargill's British fresh chicken business and all of Faccenda Foods; so as well as the latter's chicken activities the deal includes duck (Cherry Valley) and turkey businesses too; Faccenda process c100m chickens per year, which alongside Cargill will make for c200m combined annual bird output in our view.

11:47 am
PM11:48am

The new venture will be led by Andy Dawkins, the current Managing Director of Faccenda. Management believes that this will be a complementary combination, naturally, speaking of a long-term commitment to the market and 'providing stability and security to our customers, suppliers and growers for years to come. The combination comes at a time when some players have been experiencing profit pressure and challenging returns. We are not aware, nor do we really expect, two privately owned ventures to indicate potential financial synergies from the new combination but clearly central overhead rationalisation and sourcing opportunities would be expected to be early ports of call with operational integration following thereafter where appropriate

PM11:49am

Ok, Shore using this as an opportunity to highlight Cranswick

PM11:49am

A more recent new entrant into the UK poultry market is the world class Cranswick plc, the country's leading fresh pork and value added pork related manufacturing company. Cranswick acquired firstly into the poultry segment through the high value added chicken preparation field with its Benson Park purchase in Kingston-upon-Hull. That very successful acquisition, embracing considerable expansion through investment in the prepared poultry arena, latterly primarily servicing the food service market, was followed by the acquisition of Crown Chicken in 2016, the integrated feed mill, hatchery and fresh poultry processor (c25m birds per annum) based in East Anglia; a business that we visited this summer and one with considerable potential to our minds. This report is prepared solely for the use of Sales Research

11:49 am
Cranswick PLC (CWK:LSE): Last: 2,897, down 38 (-1.29%), High: 2,972, Low: 2,886, Volume: 11.86k
PM11:50am

Whilstcurrently only a modestplayerin the UK chicken market,in terms of the big scheme of things outlined above, no doubt Cranswick, which is a very well capitalised and a distinctly long-term player, will be noting wider matters with considerable interest too. Indeed, a materially concentrating British fresh chicken market, if approved, could be a potential step-forward for Cranswickin this field, which may augur very well for investors in due course.This report is prepared solely for the use of Sales Research

PM11:50am

They're the shop for Cranswick, I should note

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Hang on hang on hang on. You're talking the CMA getting excited about a four-into-three poultry cartel?

BE11:50am

But they're chickens.

BE11:51am

The barriers to entry to owning a chicken are extremely low.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

It's the principle Bryce, the principle

PM11:52am

Before you know it they'll be just three mobile providers, three banks, three grocers and so on

PM11:52am

And consumers will be crushed

11:52 am
PM11:52am

It'll be like Stalingrad

BE11:53am

Stalingrad is very much not happening with chickens.

PM11:53am

Who owns Label Rouge?

11:53 am
BE11:54am

No idea.

PM11:54am

Ah, it's just quality assurance

PM11:54am

Thought it was actually a brand

11:54 am
PM11:54am

https://en.wikiped...g/wiki/Label_Rouge

PM11:54am

Good chickens!

BE11:55am

........... we disagree.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Anyway. Chicken's probably the most deflationary grocery good over the past few decades. Competition is, appropriately enough, cut-throat.

undefined
PM11:56am

What have we missed?

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Not much. People keep mentioning Virgin Money for some reason.

Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 282.40, up 12.4 (+4.59%), High: 283.50, Low: 273.10, Volume: 1.47m
BE11:57am

There's a push from KBW.

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Think Trader Gordon was pushing this yesterday as well

BE11:57am

Oh, give us Gordon while I find KBW.

PM11:58am

Ok -- Investec from yesterday

11:57 am
PM11:58am

We think that today’s stunningly good (albeit predictable) gross mortgage lending data for August of £24.2bn gross (+10% YoY) underscores our expectation of further material operational outperformance when Virgin releases its Q3 IMS on 17 October. Meanwhile, if taken at face value, we think that yesterday’s FPC statement in relation to consumer credit stress tests (and other issues) should reassure rather than alarm. BUY reaffirmed.

PM11:58am

On an absurd 5.2x 2019e EPS, Buy rec and 395p TP reaffirmed. Virgin Money (rather clearly) remains our top pick.

PM11:58am

Ian loves it

11:59 am
BE11:59am

.......... nuts, KBW seems to have disappeared.

PM12:00pm

Ah, no worry

BE12:00pm

Anyway, there's an upgrade and I can't find it. That's why they're up. Read the paper tomorrow for detail.

12:00 pm
undefined
PM12:00pm

Look at the time

PM12:00pm

So -- get yer drinking boots on later.

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm

6pm -- Bleeding Heart Tavern

PM12:01pm

We are done here for now -- but live later today.

PM12:02pm

Bye

11:29 am
